channel.title: Making any client, a webclient
channel.description:
[b]Description:[/b] A guide on how to get your client from the files, to the web.
[b]Difficulty:[/b] About 3/10
[b]Assumed Knowledge:[/b] Basic HTML, Following simple instruction.
[b]Tested Client:[/b] Will work with 99% of clients.
[b]Files/Classes Modified:[/b] Read the damn tutorial...
In order to make this as simple as possible, this tutorial includes the use of JarMaker. Download JarMaker: [url=http://download.cnet.com/JAR-Maker/3000-2213_4-10588876.html]http://download.cnet.com/JAR-Maker/3000-2213_4-10588876.html[/url]
[b]Guide:[/b]
1.) Open [b]JarMaker[/b].
[img]http://i49.tinypic.com/2hhov2v.png[/img]
A.) In the [b][u]Output[/u][/b] box, put where you want the .jar to be placed. This does not need to be any specific place for it to work the way it should. B.) In the [b][u]Input[/u][/b], direct it to your client folder. For all who don't know, this will be the folder with all the .class and .java files in it...
C.) Select the Manifest Template Button, and in the "Main-Class" box, type: [code]client.[/code] If you already have a Manifest for your client, delete it, you won't need it after this.
Select "Create JAR".
2.) Go to the folder where you selected for "Output", and double click the .jar file that is now there, and test to see if your client starts up. A.) If it starts up, then continue on to step 3 B.) If it DOES NOT work, then delete the .jar, and repeat step 1.
3.) Open a new "Notepad" document, or your favorite Script Editing Program.
4.) Put the following HTML Script into it:
[code] <html> <head><title>My Webclient</title></head> <body bgcolor="000000"> <center> <applet name="client" width="765" height="503" archive="your jar file here.jar" code="client"> </center> </body> </html> [/code]
5.) Upload the HTML script to your hosting site, along with the jar file.
6.) Done
By: Ackroma

item.title: Making any client, a webclient
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

[quote=“jamessemple, post:5, topic:317546”][quote author=Scape-JAVA link=topic=414059.msg3049494#msg3049494 date=1259996120]
I think ric’s tutorial is alot more discriptive, this just shows how to Jar and Sign.

[/quote]
which is where alot of people get stuck believe it or not <3[/quote]

Yea, they get stuck because of the point of, this will NOT work, this is doing .class files only when you acually sit down a think about it. The cache, pictures, any hand-made edits that are not in a .class file will not load from this. Unless its inside of the folder with those.

@TOPIC - .5-10 you simply showed how to use .Jarmaker, without even explaining it well. No, this is not how you make any client a web-client, because all files need to be web-hosted or downloaded with the cache. This was a complete fail attempt at getting some rep.

Read full topic

item.title: Making any client, a webclient
item.dc:creator: @Ackroma Ackroma
item.description:
@Ackroma wrote:

Description: A guide on how to get your client from the files, to the web.

Difficulty: About 3/10

Assumed Knowledge: Basic HTML, Following simple instruction.

Tested Client: Will work with 99% of clients.

Files/Classes Modified: Read the damn tutorial…

In order to make this as simple as possible, this tutorial includes the use of JarMaker.
Download JarMaker: http://download.cnet.com/JAR-Maker/3000-2213_4-10588876.html

Guide:

1.) Open JarMaker.

A.) In the Output box, put where you want the .jar to be placed. This does not need to be any specific place for it to work the way it should.
B.) In the Input, direct it to your client folder. For all who don’t know, this will be the folder with all the .class and .java files in it…

C.) Select the Manifest Template Button, and in the “Main-Class” box, type: client.
If you already have a Manifest for your client, delete it, you won’t need it after this.

Select “Create JAR”.

2.) Go to the folder where you selected for “Output”, and double click the .jar file that is now there, and test to see if your client starts up.
A.) If it starts up, then continue on to step 3
B.) If it DOES NOT work, then delete the .jar, and repeat step 1.

3.) Open a new “Notepad” document, or your favorite Script Editing Program.

4.) Put the following HTML Script into it:

<html>
<head><title>My Webclient</title></head>
<body bgcolor="000000">
<center>
<applet name="client" width="765" height="503" archive="your jar file here.jar" code="client">
</center>
</body>
</html>

5.) Upload the HTML script to your hosting site, along with the jar file.

6.) Done

By: Ackroma

Read full topic
